abstract: A Deutsche Bank shareholder who was spied on by the German bank has sued for more details about the incident. He told DealBook in an interview Tuesday that he doesn’t believe two midlevel employees at the bank acted independently.
snippet: A Deutsche Bank shareholder who was spied on by the German bank has sued for more details about the incident. He told DealBook in an interview Tuesday that he doesn’t believe two midlevel employees at the bank acted independently.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Bohndorf picked up the phone at 8 p.m. one evening this summer, the last person he expected to talk to was the head of Deutsche Bank‘s legal department, Arne Wittig, calling to apologize.

headline.main: For Shareholder in Spying Case, Sorry Isn’t Enough
